newsitem.title: USA: PRESS DIGEST - Wall Street Journal - June 2.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Wall Street Journal - June 2.

text.p: The following stories were reported in Monday's electronic version of The Wall Street Journal:
* PepsiCo Inc to reorganise its North American bottling operations by creating a separate unit.
* Tobacco settlement talks remain mired in an internal fight over whether to give the industry full immunity from punitive damages.
* A tobacco suit filed by non-smoking flight attendants begins today in Miami.
* Intel Corp warned that its second-quarter results would be disappointing, largely because of weak demand in Europe.
* Corporate profit margins rose to 11.8 percent of output in the first quarter from 11.5 percent in the fourth quarter.
* Lockheed Martin Corp is expected to announce a joint satellite venture with Intersputnik, a Russian consortium.
* Andersen Worldwide's board has nominated George Shaheen to become chief executive, succeeding Lawrence Weinbach, who is set to retire in August.
* The U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission is seeking to join a racial discrimination class-action lawsuit against United Parcel Service of America Inc.
* Westinghouse Electric Corp has named Ernest Drew head of its industrial operations.
* PointCast Inc has begun a search for chief executive in preparation of a likely initial public offering.
* Archer Daniels Midland Co has proposed adopting several corporate governance measures to settle 17 shareholder lawsuits over its price-fixing scandal.
* IVAX Corp has a definitive agreement to sell its McGaw Inc unit to a unit of B. Braun Melsungen AG, a privately held medical products manufacturer in Germany.
* Coca-Cola Co is expected to announce that its Powerade will be the official drink of choice by the National Hockey League.

* Heard on the Street: While big rivals such as Chase Manhattan, NationsBank and Wells Fargo staged one acquisition after another in the 1990s, Citicorp has largely been content to remain on the sidelines, losing its rank as the largest U.S. bank in the process. Now, the nation's second-largest bank is signalling it might finally be ready to rumba.
* Credit Markets: Bond investors begin the trading week still exuberant over Friday's strong rally, but also wary that crucial economic data this week could include some unpleasant surprises.
